docs.abstract: New rail link between Beijing and Hong Kong is established (S)

headline.main: A New Orient Express: Beijing to Hong Kong

docs.snippet: The return of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty is not the only link forged in recent weeks between Beijing and the former British colony. In May, about six weeks before the handover, the two cities were connected by a direct express train on a new no
docs.lead_paragraph: The return of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty is not the only link forged in recent weeks between Beijing and the former British colony. In May, about six weeks before the handover, the two cities were connected by a direct express train on a new north-south trunk line. Rail passengers can now stay on one train for the 30-hour, 1,410-mile trip. Previously they had to change trains in Shenzhen, just across the border from Hong Kong, adding about four hours to the trip. (By plane, it takes about two and a half hours.)

docs.abstract: Health experts from around world are gathering for conference on smoking, Beijing, as China emerges as world's next and largest battleground between tobacco companies and anti-smoking campaigners; China's vast and increasing smoking population poses daunting challenge to health experts and offers hugely lucrative market for tobacco companies; Chinese tobacco companies are virtually all state-owned and provide about 10 percent of Government's revenue (M)

headline.main: China Next In the War To Depose Cigarettes

docs.snippet: As health experts from around the world gathered here this week for a conference on smoking, it seemed obvious to many that China will become the world's next and largest battleground between tobacco companies and anti-smoking campaigners.     The en
docs.lead_paragraph: As health experts from around the world gathered here this week for a conference on smoking, it seemed obvious to many that China will become the world's next and largest battleground between tobacco companies and anti-smoking campaigners. The enormous size of China's smoking population -- estimated at 320 million -- poses a dauntingly large challenge to health experts, just as it offers a hugely lucrative market for tobacco companies.

docs.abstract: Photo of demonstration, Hong Kong, recalling June 4, 1989 massacre of demonstrators near Tiananmen Square, Beijing

headline.main: In Hong Kong, a Remembrance of the Tiananmen Massacre

docs.abstract: China plans $25 million renovation of Forbidden City, Beijing palace complex, mostly along exterior walls; says renovation will not affect visitors; map (M)

headline.main: The Forbidden City Gets a Face Lift

docs.snippet: OF all China's illustrious and history-rich places to visit, perhaps none is quite so stunning in scope and design as the Forbidden City, the palace complex where emperors once lived and ruled.     It may also be the hardest to keep up. A vast collec
docs.lead_paragraph: OF all China's illustrious and history-rich places to visit, perhaps none is quite so stunning in scope and design as the Forbidden City, the palace complex where emperors once lived and ruled. It may also be the hardest to keep up. A vast collection of courtyards and enormous halls and former living quarters spread out over 250 acres, the Forbidden City is forever fighting crumbling walls, decaying roofs and shaky pavilions.

docs.abstract: 'Bread-loaf taxis' have become Beijing's most popular mode of transportation, except for city's overcrowded buses; few people own cars in China, partly because they are still so expensive and partly because lingering socialist mentality encourages new moneymakers to hide their wealth; well-to-do entrepreneurs favor Audis or Mercedes-Benzes that technically belong to their companies; photo (Special Sections, Cars) (M)

headline.main: How Many Passengers Can Cram Into a Rickety Bread Loaf?

docs.snippet: SHAO BING is a man on the move.    Only problem is, he can't move very fast. Only now and then does Mr. Shao find a few yards of open road on Beijing's congested streets, and when he does, he floors the gas pedal of his tiny, dilapidated van. Nothing
docs.lead_paragraph: SHAO BING is a man on the move. Only problem is, he can't move very fast. Only now and then does Mr. Shao find a few yards of open road on Beijing's congested streets, and when he does, he floors the gas pedal of his tiny, dilapidated van. Nothing happens. One, two, three seconds go by -- a seemingly interminable wait in car time -- until his vehicle finally gains a little speed, just in time to brake again behind an open-backed truck that swerves into his lane.

docs.abstract: British diplomats at talks, Beijing, on Hong Kong after Chinese takeover raise issues of democracy and human rights; Alan Paul, leader of British delegation, refrains from publicly criticizing abolition of fully elected legislature or methods for choosing new one (M)

headline.main: 5 Months After Handover, New Talks on Hong Kong's Progress

docs.snippet: For the first time since Britain returned Hong Kong to Chinese rule five months ago, British diplomats met with Chinese officials in Beijing this week and raised issues of democracy and human rights.    China has repeatedly declared that Britain now
docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since Britain returned Hong Kong to Chinese rule five months ago, British diplomats met with Chinese officials in Beijing this week and raised issues of democracy and human rights. China has repeatedly declared that Britain now has no responsibility to monitor or judge Beijing's policies toward Hong Kong. But, despite Britain's status as nothing more than the former colonial power, the original agreement between the two countries in 1984 called for continued discussions through 2000.
